column1: Hunucmá Municipality (In the Yucatec Maya Language: “only answers”) is one of the 106 municipalities in the Mexican state of Yucatán containing  (599.10 km2) of land and located roughly 25 km west of the city of Mérida.

It is unknown which chieftainship the area was under prior to the arrival of the Spanish. After the conquest the area became part of the encomienda system. The encomienda was established under Francisco de Montejo the Younger in 1549 and by 1571 it had passed to Beatriz de Montejo. In 1579 the encomendero was Diego de Santillán and in 1607 it passed to Martín de Palomar. In 1616 the encomenderos were Diego García de Montalvo
column3: and Martín de Montalvo y Figueroa
column4: but by 1678 it had passed to Diego Tello de Aguillar.Yucatán declared its independence from the Spanish Crown in 1821 and in 1825
column5: the area was assigned to the Camino Real Bajo region with its headquarters in Hunucmá Municipality
column14: and Umán. After the ejidos and land redistribution of the 1930s
column15: Hunucmá was reconfirmed as head of its own municipality.

column1: The municipal president is elected for a three-year term. The town council has nine councilpersons
column2: who serve as Secretary and councilors of public lighting
column10: and sports.The Municipal Council administers the business of the municipality. It is responsible for budgeting and expenditures and producing all required reports for all branches of the municipal administration. Annually it determines educational standards for schools.The Police Commissioners ensure public order and safety. They are tasked with enforcing regulations
column11: distributing materials and administering rulings of general compliance issued by the council.

column1: The head of the municipality is Hunucmá
column2: Yucatán.  The other populated areas of the municipality include Capel

column1: Every year from 10 to 15 August there is a festival of the Virgin of the Assumption; on 28 to 31 January
column2: the feast of Corpus Christi is celebrated; and the last week of August
column3: in Sisal is a celebration in honor of the Christ of Hunucmá.
